title-group.article-title: Effects of gamma radiation on the mechanical properties of and susceptibility to biodegradation of natural fibers

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Material and Commodity Sciences and Textile Metrology, Technical University of Lodz, Lodz, Poland
2Institute of Fermentation Technology and Microbiology, Technical University of Lodz, Lodz, Poland
3Institute of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Technical University of Lodz, Lodz, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Waldemar Machnowski, Department of Material and Commodity Sciences and Textile Metrology, Technical University of Lodz, Zeromskiego 116, 90-924 Lodz, Poland. Email: waldemar.machnowski@p.lodz.pl

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The effect of gamma radiation on the mechanical properties and surface structure of woven fabrics made of cotton, flax, and silk fibers was investigated. It was found that small radiation doses (up to 15 kGy), sufficient for effective disinfection of textiles, caused only insignificant changes in the fiber parameters tested. However, it was found that doses increased to 100 kGy bring about a considerable weakening of the tested fabrics——their tensile strength decreases by 26–33%. Microbiological examination has shown that preradiation of cotton and linen fabric samples with a dose of 100 kGy does not affect the susceptibility of these fabrics to fungal biodegradation. A silk fabric irradiated under the same conditions shows clear susceptibility to bacterial biodegradation.

body.p: With the development of radiation techniques, both gamma radiation and electron beam radiation have found more and more fields of application. One of the areas of use of ionizing radiation involves polymeric materials, including textile products.1 Radiation techniques have proved useful in some processes for the finishing and modification of textiles, such as graft-copolymerization of styrene and acrylonitrile on jute fibers,2,3 preparing grafted cellulose with hydrogel properties,4 and flame-retardant finishing of cotton fabrics,5 and these techniques are used as an effective method of sterilization of textile dressings and others medical textiles.6,7

In the 1950s attempts were made to use ionizing radiation for the disinfection of various types of historical objects that were inhabited by microorganisms (e.g., fungi and bacteria) or insects, which ended up causing the objects’ destruction.8,9 Radiation disinfection has proved to be an effective method of biological hazard mitigation in historical objects made of wood, leather, paper, and woven fabrics. 10 Natural fibers of plant origin (e.g. cotton and flax) and animal origin (e.g. wool and silk) constitute the material of many valuable antique objects, works of art, and ethnographic exhibits. The use of gamma radiation can be an effective and useful method for the disinfection of these objects.11 However, one should bear in mind that ionizing radiation has a destructive effect on many polymeric materials and may lead to deterioration in their mechanical, physical, and chemical properties.

The effects of gamma radiation on the mechanical, physicochemical, and optical properties of several commercial plastic products (e.g. food-packaging films and materials for medical applications) have been investigated by many authors.7,12,13 Several researchers have also examined the effect of gamma radiation on some properties of textiles, mainly cellulosic, protein, and polyamide fibers.2,6,14–16 Ferreira et al.,6 using gamma radiation of 80 kGy, found that the tensile strength of cellulose-polyester nonwoven fabric designed for medical applications was decreased by about 10%. They also showed the effect of the applied gamma radiation doses on the thermal properties of cellulose and polyester fibers. The tests performed by Awan et al.2 showed the destructive effect of gamma radiation on jute fibers—irradiation with a dose of 37 kGy decreased their tensile strength by 24%. Takacs et al.14 studied the effects of gamma-irradiation on cotton fibers and found that this process resulted in the formation of carbonyl groups as a consequence of the oxidative degradation of cellulose. Borsa et al.16 investigated the effect of accessibility of cotton cellulose molecules on the development of crosslinks during gamma irradiation and found that the number of crosslinks formed depends on the water content of the cotton fibers.

The deterioration in some functional properties of textile fabrics due to the effects of ionizing radiation is an important issue from the research point of view and has a clear practical aspect. The deterioration in fabric parameters that takes place during radiation (observed directly after radiation) is of major importance; however, no less important is the effect of absorbed radiation doses on the aging of fibers and their biodegradation in the future. The latter issue, although very significant with regard to the use of ionizing radiation for the disinfection of textile historical objects, has not yet been the subject of investigation.

In this study, woven fabrics of natural fibers (specifically, cotton, flax, and silk) were subjected to various doses of gamma radiation (from 5 to 100 kGy), and then their mechanical properties and changes in their surface morphology were examined. It was also an objective of this work to investigate the effect of irradiation on the growth of microorganisms on the tested fabrics and their susceptibility to biodegradation.

sec.title: Textile fabrics
sec.p:
The basic characteristics of the tested woven fabrics are given in Table 1. The fabrics contained no dyes, auxiliary agents, or optical brightening agents. The cotton fabric was bleached with hydrogen peroxide. The linen fabric was not bleached, having the color of natural flax fibers. The silk fabric was degummed, without sericin content (a mixture of proteins that coats the fibroin fibers). The porosity of fabrics (P) was calculated from the formula: P=(1-MT·ρ)100% where M is the mass per unit area of fabric (in g/m2), T is the thickness of fabric (in mm) and ρ is the density of fiber (in kg/m3). Table 1.
Characteristics of tested fabrics
Fiber Mass per unit area (M) g/m2 Thickness (T) mm Porosity (P) %
Cotton 210 0.36 62
Flax 225 0.44 66
Silk 52 0.12 67
The following values of fiber density were used in calculations:17,18 cotton 1550 kg/m3; flax 1500 kg/m3; silk 1340 kg/m3.

sec.title: Microorganisms and media
sec.p: The selection criteria for choosing microorganisms for this study were the frequency of fabric contamination and the ability to degrade the natural fibers. As determined in earlier studies, mold has a high cellulolytic activity;19 hence, it was chosen for growing on cotton and linen fabrics, while the bacteria tested readily settle on silk fibers and degrade silk proteins.20 The fungi Trichoderma viride, Aspergillus niger, and Penicillium funiculosum were used, as well as the bacteria Bacillus megaterium, Pseudomonas fluorescens, and Streptomyces sp. The microorganisms were derived from the LOCK Collection of Pure Cultures at the Institute of Technology Fermentation and Microbiology, Technical University of Lodz. They were grown on microbiological culture media: for the fungi—MEA medium (malt extract agar, Oxoid), incubation at 27°C for seven days and for the bacteria—TSA (tryptic soy agar, Merck), incubation at 27°C for 24 hours (P. fluorescens) or 37°C for 24 hours (B. megaterium, Streptomyces sp.).

sec.title: Irradiation of fabric samples
sec.p: The woven fabrics under investigation were irradiated in a gamma chamber, using a cobalt source (Co-60) that emits gamma rays with a quantum energy of 1.25 MeV. The fabric samples were conditioned for 24 hours at a temperature of 20°C and relative humidity (RH) of 65%, then they were placed in paper envelopes and irradiated at ambient temperature with the following doses: 5, 10, 25, and 100 kGy. The radiation dose rate was 1 kGy/h.

The low irradiation doses (5 and 10 kGy) simulated the conditions of the radiation disinfection of textile objects performed to obtain bactericidal and fungicidal effects. The higher dose of gamma radiation (25 kGy) is the standard dose used for sterilization of materials for medical applications.1,13 Gamma irradiation at a dose of 100 kGy was applied in order to bring about distinct changes in the parameters of the fabrics and fibers and, thereby, to enable them to be more easily and accurately analyzed. High radiation doses, exceeding 100 kGy, have been used in textile testing by Ferreira et al.6 and Takacs et al.14

sec.title: Culture of microorganisms on fabrics
sec.p: Fabric samples irradiated with a dose of 100 kGy, as well as unirradiated control samples, were prepared. All samples (72 cm2 each) were sterilized with steam (at 121°C for 15 minutes) and then overlaid with microorganism suspension in a quantity of 0.025 ml/cm2 of area. The average density of the suspension of microorganisms was about 107 CFU/ml (the density of inoculum was established by the culture method). At the beginning of the culture, mineral nutrient medium (signed as Mo) [MgSO4 × 7H2O (5 g/l), (NH4)2SO4 (3 g/l), KH2PO4 (1 g/l), glucose (20 g/l), pH 5.5] was added to the materials to initiate microbial growth and establish the maximal mass humidity of the fabrics. The culture was grown in a climatic chamber (KBF 720, Binder GmbH, Germany) for 5 weeks at a temperature of 27°C (fungi and bacteria—P. fluorescens) and 37°C (bacteria—B. megaterium and Streptomyces sp.) at RH 80%.

sec.title: Determination of microbial growth on fabrics
sec.p: Samples of fabrics with microorganisms were taken after 1, 7, 14, 21, and 35 days from the material inoculation (samples from particular incubation times were taken from separate materials, in three repetitions). The fabric samples were subsequently transferred to saline (volume 100 ml) to wash out the microorganisms from the fabric and shaken for 20 minutes (in an elliptical motion at a rate of 110 cycles/minute and amplitude of 10 mm) at a temperature of 27°C. The samples were diluted in sterile saline and seeded in a sterile Petri dish, and subsequently poured over with half-liquid TSA (bacteria) or MEA (fungi) medium, mixed, and left for cooling. Next the samples were incubated at 37°C for 24 hours (bacteria), at 27°C for 72 hours (fungi), or at 27°C for 24 hours (P. fluorescens), and after that time, the colonies were counted and expressed as CFU/ml (colony forming units isolated from an area of 72 cm2). The mean value for each microorganism was calculated for each time of incubation and each textile material.

The microorganisms’ growth rate was calculated mathematically. The growth of microorganisms on textile fabrics was described by the mathematical exponential function; based on these model functions, a derivative was determined and then the highest value of the derivative that described the maximum growth rate, µmax (CFU/ml·day), was determined. To establish model functions and to determine the parameter µmax, the Origin 7.1 computer program was used. An ANOVA statistical analysis was performed to assess statistical differences between the number of microorganisms on the fabric samples irradiated and unirradiated before incubation.

sec.title: Mechanical tests
sec.p: The mechanical tests of fabric samples conditioned for 24 hours at a temperature of 20°C and RH of 65% were carried out with the use of a tensile testing machine, INSTRON Model 4204. The values of breaking force (Fmax) and elongation at break (εbr) were determined. The test method described in ISO13934-1:200221 was used for determining these parameters.

The fabric samples irradiated with doses of 5, 10, 25, and 100 kGy measured 50 mm × 250 mm. The tests were conducted at a crosshead speed of 100 mm/min and a grip distance of 100 mm. The average values of Fmax and εbr for the five samples were calculated. The fabric samples irradiated with a dose of 100 kGy and then subjected to the incubation of microorganisms measured 15 mm × 120 mm (they were cut out from the 60 mm × 120 mm fabrics sections used in a culture of fungi or bacteria). The tests were conducted at a crosshead speed of 50 mm/min and a grip distance of 50 mm. The average values of Fmax and εbr for the three samples were calculated.

sec.title: Analysis of fiber surface
sec.p: The analysis of the surface morphology of fibers in the fabric samples after irradiation and microorganism incubation was carried out with the use of a scanning electron microscope, NOVA NANOSEM 230 (FEI). The same method for the analysis of the changes in surface morphology of cotton fibers exposed to gamma radiation was used by many authors.4,14,16

The fabric samples on which microorganisms has been cultivated were treated with saline (as described in the ‘Determination of microbial growth on fabrics’ section) and distilled water to remove the microbiological film, which masked the details of the fiber surface structure. The same procedure was applied to the control samples (with no microorganisms). All the fabric samples were coated with gold before the SEM observation.

sec.title: Growth of microorganisms on unirradiated and irradiated fabrics
sec.p: Statistical analysis showed that in most cases, there was a statistically significant difference between the numbers of fungi and bacteria on the fabrics subjected and not subjected to radiation. The only exception was in the case of A. niger on cotton; no statistically significant differences were found in the fungal growth between irradiated and unirradiated fabric samples before incubation.

Based on the results presented in Table 2, we can see that the pre-irradiation of cotton with a dose of 100 kGy has resulted in a slightly lower growth of T. viride and P. funiculosum mold. The pre-irradiation of linen fabric under the same conditions caused a decrease in the growth of T. viride and an increase in the growth of P. funiculosum. The irradiation of silk samples with a dose of 100 kGy increased the growth of bacteria B. megaterium. In the case of P. fluorescens, it can be concluded that the pre-irradiation of silk fabric has either a positive or negative effect on the growth of these bacteria, depending on the stage of incubation (Table 2). In the case of Streptomyces sp., after silk fabric irradiation, the rate of growth of these bacteria was observed to be one level of magnitude slower than on unirradiated samples.

The irradiation of fabric samples caused some changes in the molecular and supermolecular structure of fiber polymers (cellulose and fibroin) and noncellulosic impurities contained in plant fibers.4,14 These changes may lead to some differences in the biological environment during the incubation of microorganisms tested and thus also affect their growth rate.

Cao and Wang25 found that the biodegradation behavior of silk may depend on a protease inhibitor produced by silk itself. It can be assumed that this factor also affects the growth conditions for the bacteria tested in this study.

sec.title: Changes in the mechanical properties of fabrics due to gamma radiation and microbial activity
sec.p:
The results of tests of the mechanical properties of fabrics after irradiation indicate a clear effect of gamma radiation dose on the values of breaking force (Fmax) and elongation at break (εbr) (see Table 3). Irradiation doses up to 25 kGy cause greater losses of the strength of silk fabric than that of cellulose fabric. The use of a considerably higher dose reveals a change in the degree of sensitivity of particular fibers to irradiation. Cotton fabric, after irradiation with a dose of 100 kGy, loses almost 28% of its tensile strength. A very similar decrease in breaking force (about 26%) was observed for silk fabric. These results confirm that cellulose (the main component of cotton fibers) and fibroin (a single protein in silk matter) show similar sensitivity to high doses of gamma radiation. This similar behavior of cotton and silk fibers is somewhat surprising if one takes into account that silk is more sensitive to many destructive factors than cotton. For example, the high sensitivity of silk fibers to UV radiation is commonly known, and, consequently, their resistance to exposure to sunlight is very low—considerably lower than that of cotton fibers.17 Table 3.
Tensile strength (Fmax) and elongation at break (εbr) of fabrics after gamma irradiation with various doses
No. Dose of radiation, kGy Fmax, N εbr, % Relative decrease in parameter values of fabrics caused by irradiation, %
Fmax εbr
cotton fabric

2. 5 750 ± 15# 13.4 ± 0.7# 0.2 1.2
3. 10 708 ± 7* 12.7 ± 0.8# 5.8 6.4
4. 25 683 ± 14* 12.5 ± 0.4* 9.1 7.7
5. 100 543 ± 9* 11.3 ± 0.5* 27.6 16.2
linen fabric
6. 0 (control) 948 ± 43 11.9 ± 0.6 – –

8. 10 864 ± 27* 11.8 ± 0.5# 8.8 1.2
9. 25 848 ± 30* 11.3 ± 0.8# 10.5 5.0
10. 100 634 ± 51* 9.7 ± 0.5* 33.2 18.7
silk fabric
11. 0 (control) 348 ± 5 33.7 ± 0.6 – –
12. 5 319 ± 6* 32.8 ± 1.0# 8.4 2.8
13. 25 300 ± 9* 31.7 ± 2.4# 13.8 6.1
14. 100 258 ± 4* 26.0 ± 1.1* 25.8 23.0
*Statistically significant differences between samples irradiated and unirradiated (control) (ANOVA, p < 0.05).
#No statistically significant differences (ANOVA, p > 0.05).

Among the fabrics tested, it is the linen fabric that shows the lowest resistance to the highest applied dose of ionizing radiation (100 kGy). The tensile strength of this fabric after irradiation is decreased by about 33%. Flax, like cotton, is a plant cellulose fiber; however, these fibers clearly differ in anatomical structure—cotton is a mono-cell fiber (i.e. each cotton fiber is a single plant cell), while flax is a multicell stem fiber (noncellulosic impurities—hemicellulose, lignin, and pectin—bond the small individual fibrous cells together into a long fiber26). It can be assumed that this considerable decrease in the breaking force of linen fabric under the influence of irradiation with a dose of 100 kGy is due not only to the degradation of the small individual flax fibers but also to the degradation of some noncellulosic impurities, which bond these small individual fibers. The tests performed by Awan et al.2 showed that jute (like flax, a multicell stem fiber) also has a low resistance to gamma radiation; the breaking strength of jute yarn after irradiation with a dose of 37 kGy is decreased by 24%.

In general, one can state that irradiation of the fabrics with doses of 5–25 kGy does not cause a drastic deterioration in their mechanical properties. In no case did the loss of tensile strength exceed 14%. It should be mentioned that the tensile strength of cellulose fabrics during some technological processes (e.g. crease resistant and flame-retardant finishing of cotton fabrics) is reduced by 15–20%.27,28

All of the fabrics tested showed a clear trend toward reduced elongation of samples due to irradiation with a high dose of 100 kGy (see Table 3). This is a characteristic symptom of the aging process in polymeric materials. Both the chain scission and cross-linking of the fiber-forming polymer molecules may cause a decrease in the elongation at break of fabrics, which is observed when they are subjected to heat and biological factors, as well as when they are exposed to UV or gamma radiation.29–31 As it is known, cellulose is the predominantly degrading polymer when exposed to gamma radiation. Takacs et al.4 found that the irradiation (with a dose of 40 kGy) of cotton cellulose decreases its degree of polymerization by about 86%.

The results of testing of the mechanical properties of fabrics after microbial incubation lasting 35 days (see Table 4) show that the extent of sample destruction differs distinctly depending on the type of fiber and strain of microorganisms being tested. The fungi used in the tests (T. viride, A. niger, and P. funiculosum) cause a clearly greater destruction of flax fiber than of cotton fiber. Table 4.

The greatest losses in the tensile strength of cotton fabric do not exceed 16%, while they amount to more than 73% in the case of linen fabric samples. Such a great difference in susceptibility to biodegradation between flax and cotton fibers cannot be explained only by the slightly more intensive growth of fungi on the linen fabric samples. It seems that an important cause of the lower resistance of flax fiber under the conditions of the tests is the sensitivity of some noncellulosic components of these fibers. As previously mentioned, these components (hemicellulose, lignin, and pectins), constituting in total about 20% of flax fiber mass,26 are the substances that bond together the small individual fibrous cells into long fibers. Thus, the biodegradation of some of these noncellulosic substances can result in a clear decrease in the mechanical strength of the linen fabric samples. In the case of cotton mono-cell fibers, composed of more than 90% cellulose, their susceptibility to biodegradation is determined by the properties of cellulose. This polymer has proven relatively resistant to damage due to the incubation of the microorganisms used here.

The enzymatic degradation of the noncellulosic parts of the bast fibers plays a key role in the retting processes of flax and hemp fibers. Retting is a microbial process that allows separation of the bast fibers from the stems of the plant fibers. High activity in retting processes has been demonstrated by, among others, Epicoccum nigrum.23

The results listed in Table 4 indicate that among the three fungi tested, it is A. niger that shows the least destructive effect on both irradiated and unirradiated cellulose fabrics. The tensile strength tests of cotton fabric have shown even a lack of statistically significant differences between the samples before and after incubation of A. niger. In the case of both tested cellulose fabrics, the greatest losses of strength occurred during the incubation of P. funiculosum. It has been found that this fungus causes a decrease in the breaking force of linen fabric by more than 73% (see Table 4).

The results listed in Table 4 show that previous irradiation of cotton and linen fabric samples does not increase their susceptibility to biodegradation under the fungi incubation conditions used. In some cases, the samples irradiated with a dose of 100 kGy before microbial incubation show even slightly smaller decreases in tensile strength than the unirradiated samples.

Different results were obtained in tests of the mechanical properties of silk fabric after the bacterial incubation of B. megaterium, P. fluorescens, and Streptomyces sp. The samples of this fabric, previously irradiated with a dose of 100 kGy (see Table 4), are characterized by a clearly higher susceptibility to biodegradation. These bacteria caused considerably greater reductions in the tensile strength of the irradiated silk fabric samples. This is an interesting and unexpected result, since the bacteria growth tests on silk fabric do not show more intensive growth by these microbes on irradiated fabric samples (see Table 2). This seems to indicate that the changes in the molecular and supermolecular structure of fibroin (silk matter) due to irradiation with a dose of 100 kGy bring about an increased susceptibility of silk fibers to bacterial damage.

The growth of microorganisms does not cause significant changes in the elongation at break of any of the fabrics tested. However, cotton fabric samples after incubation show a slight increase in this parameter (see Table 4). Yet, the results of tension tests on the silk fabric show that bacteria Streptomyces sp. cause not only the greatest loss of strength but also a clear decrease in the elongation at break of silk fibers.

sec.title: Changes in the morphology of fiber surface caused by gamma radiation and microbial activity
sec.p:
The results of the examination of fiber surface morphology in unirradiated fabric samples and those irradiated with a dose of 100 kGy are presented in the form of SEM images in Figures 1–7. Among the samples examined, only cotton fibers show changes in the structure of their surface due to the absorption of the aforementioned radiation dose. In the SEM image (Figure 1b), one can observe some local longitudinal cracks in the secondary cell wall of cotton fibers, which attest to the weakening of intermolecular interaction in the cotton fibrillar structure. Similar cracks on the surface of cotton fibers irradiated with a dose of 200 kGy were observed by Takacs et al.14 Figure 1.
SEM images of cotton fibers surface (magnification 10,000x): (a) before irradiation; (b) after irradiation with 100 kGy.
Figure 7.
SEM images of silk fibers surface (no bacteria incubation) after treatment in saline solution as in the case of fibers in Figure 6 (magnification 10,000x): (a) unirradiated, (b) irradiated with 100 kGy before treating with saline.

The microscopic images of the surface of flax and silk fibers after the absorption of a dose of 100 kGy show no visible differences in comparison with unirradiated fibers (Figures 2 and 3). This seems to indicate that the decrease in the mechanical strength of linen fabric (by more than 33%) and silk fabric (by about 26%) due to their irradiation is not reflected by changes in the fibers’ surface. Figure 2.
SEM images of linen fibers surface (magnification 5000x): (a) before irradiation, (b) after irradiation with 100 kGy.
Figure 3.
SEM images of silk fibers surface (magnification 5000x): (a) before irradiation, (b) after irradiation with 100 kGy.

Figures 4–7 show selected SEM images of fiber surface in fabric samples after microbial incubation. The fungi (P. funiculosum, A. niger, and T. viride) under the conditions of incubation caused no marked destructive changes in the surface of the cellulose fibers. From the comparison of the cotton and flax fiber images after incubation (Figures 4 and 5) with those of the fibers before incubation (Figures 1 and 2), it is seen that the 35-day incubation of P. funiculosum revealed the fibrillar structure on the surface of these fibers. The observed changes in the surface morphology of fibers caused by fungal incubation occur to the same extent in the fibers irradiated with a dose of 100 kGy and in unirradiated fibers. The incubation of A. niger and T. viride caused similar changes in the surface of cotton and flax fibers. Figure 4.
SEM images of cotton fibers surface after P. funiculosum incubation and treatment in saline solution—see the ‘Determination of microbial growth on fabrics’ section (magnification 10,000x): (a) unirradiated, (b) irradiated with 100 kGy before incubation.
Figure 5.
SEM images of linen fibers surface after P. funiculosum incubation and treatment in saline solution—see the ‘Determination of microbial growth on fabrics’ section (magnification 10,000 x): (a) unirradiated, (b) irradiated with 100 kGy before incubation.

Figure 6 shows some SEM images of the silk fiber surface after bacterial incubation (Streptomyces sp.). Tensile tests show that this bacteria strain causes the greatest reduction in the strength of silk fabric (see Table 4). The SEM images of the fiber surface, after incubation of Streptomyces sp. and intensive treatment in saline solution (see the ‘Determination of microbial growth on fabrics’ section) and with distilled water to remove the bacterial biofilm, reveal a very high degree of fibrillation of the silk fiber outer layer in both unirradiated and irradiated samples. The silk fibers’ surface in the control samples (no bacterial incubation) also shows a high degree of fibrillation (Figure 7). This indicates that the observed damage to the silk fibers’ surface can take place due to the intensive aqueous treatment performed in order to remove the bacterial biofilm from the surface of the silk fibers before SEM analysis. The method used for the preparation of all tested fabric samples for SEM observation, in the case of silk fabric, did not allow us to observe any characteristic changes in the fiber surface occurring during the incubation of bacteria. However, it should be mentioned that the treatment of unirradiated silk fabric samples after B. megaterium and P. fluorescens incubation to remove the bacterial biofilm—despite that it leads to a clear fibrillation of the fiber surface layer—causes no statistically significant losses of tensile strength (see Table 4). Figure 6.
SEM images of silk fibers surface after Streptomyces sp. incubation and treatment in saline solution—see the ‘Determination of microbial growth on fabrics’ section (magnification 10,000x): (a) unirradiated, (b) irradiated with 100 kGy before incubation.

Incubation of B. megaterium and P. fluorescens on silk fabric samples and their treatment to remove the biofilm resulted in very similar changes in the surface morphology to those observed after the incubation of Streptomyces sp.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Gamma radiation in doses not exceeding 15 kGy does not cause significant deterioration in the mechanical properties of cotton, linen, and silk fabrics. A dose of 100 kGy leads to a clear weakening of these fabrics; the greatest destructive effect is observed in linen fabric. The SEM observations show slight visible damage to the surface layer of fibers only in the case of cotton fabric. Previous irradiation of the fabrics with a dose of 100 kGy does not cause more intensive growth of microorganisms on these fabrics. The previous irradiation of cotton and linen fabrics does not increase their susceptibility to biodegradation during fungal growth. Silk fabric samples irradiated with a dose of 100 kGy show a clearly higher susceptibility to bacterial biodegradation than unirradiated samples.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
